name: Introductions and a questionable Str-based Assassin request
author: Agadris

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Hello Mighty ECBers! 

First and foremost, I feel a strong obligation to point out that yours is probably the greatest community I've ever encountered on the Internet (not that I've been a member of that many ones tbh... but still...) You people are great! 

Stag, Mick, Orion, Empyre, Valerfor, DontPlayAnymore and others (sorry guys but you are quite many to list all of you:)... I've been following this community for 6 months by now (spent them in a remote corner of Africa without any proper access to the Internet, hence reading was the only option) and I've been amazed not only by the vast knowledge of the game collected by you, distinguished sirs, but also by how this community functions and lives: in harmony but with a healthy spirit of competition, with readiness to give each other a hand but in constant search of the truth (i.e. powaaa building;)... 

Thank you, guys, for everything you've accomplished here together and separately!

Now, I probably should've taken all this to the Introductions but... can't wait to request a character (besides it's been sometime since anybody published a new build - correct me if I'm wrong;). So following the guidelines by Kail:

1) PvM; I plan to take this char on a quest through all the original content and then modules like SoF, Aielund Saga, MoTS, etc.

2) Level cap - 40 but I'd also appreciate the adjustments for different playthroughs depending on the modules and what they offer in terms of level cap.

3) Race preference - human or maybe elf. 

4) Class preference - I've been thinking a strength-based assassin with nice AB and Saves (I have a thing for those - them being below 20+ raises concerns in me) and it came to my attention that there are no builds that would include Bard, Blackguard and Assassin. Do you think it can and/or should be remedied?

5) Melee preference - Dual-wielding. It is something that I'd call my guilty pleasure: I understand that irl the concept holds no feasibility unless it's a sword/saber/rapier and a short dagger combo and even then it's not every swordsman's cup of tea but NWN is a fantasy RPG, right? I also can predict comments on how the build could be feat-starved because a nice Bard song and ability to sneak in Full Plate are something I'd want in the build as well. But, perhaps, there is a way to circumvent it?

6) Range preference - 

7) Weapon preference - I know that a shortsword or kukri  must be here but... scimitars (c'mon who doesn't want, at least at some point of their nwn-life, to build a character based on Drizzt? Well, in this case let's overlook the alignment differences.) 

8) Maximum item enhancement - I guess this depends on the modules mentioned above?

9) Spellcasting - Bard goodies are nice to have but they shouldn't be the focus of the build. I would rather they were treated as a supplementary tool in the build's arsenal (Darkness seems a good way to replace HiPS; Blank Mind and Dispells would be most useful I guess?). A nice bard song is a welcome, though.

The build that got me inspired is this one viewtopic.php?f=11&t=515486&p=167&hilit ... assin#p167  It has it flaws, I know. The reason I thought about substituting fighter with BG is the saves and BG's synergy with bard's spellcasting; and bard is there primarily because bards have access to MS and Hide and, unlike rangers, can be evil (at least in my books).

So that's it. I really look forward to your suggestions and I hope you don't find the build's concept too absurd.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello Agadris, and welcome aboard! You've got me blushing already (more like Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer than a stag right now) . I, for one, am merely "standing on the shoulders of giants" (Isaac Newton) as far as knowledge and building are concerned, but I can lap up flattery with the best of them.

As to the request, it's way out of my comfort zone, but I've got a few bits of food for thought for you before the likes of Mick or Valerfor come along, none of which fit your request exactly, but might help in the thought process.

Shadow Avenger
Codename: Stingray
Subtle Death
Paragon of Pain

Just wanted to say good to have you along for the ride, really!

Cheers

EDIT: Could have sworn your name was Leo when I first looked here!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Welcome to the guild Agadris, you're right about dual-wielding, it is mostly a gimmick unless it is performrmed by one of the best practitioners in the world (that I have seen, at least)...

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Well, now that's just showing off, isn't it? And besides, he still doesn't get the grass cut

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Thanks Stag! I feel like I've done Shadow Avenger wrong by overlooking it. It's a solid build that I might consider in case there's no way to go with the combo I'm looking for. Paragon of Pain is a cool build for a pure melee gameplay, Codename: Stingray has 3 APR which I'm a bit uncomfortable with. As to Subtle Death... as I've mentioned before, rangers, in my opinion, cannot be evil. Not by their own choice, at least.

As to my name... that was my whim to change it for the one I usually use for my characters

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: Welcome to the guild Agadris, you're right about dual-wielding, it is mostly a gimmick unless it is performrmed by one of the best practitioners in the world (that I have seen, at least)...

Valerfor, this is a very cool video actually and the guy is plain awesome at managing those blades!!! I wonder, though, if he doesn't get caught in his patterns which could be used by a pro-swordsman to break through his whirlwind movement using a shield. Additionally, the technique looks very taxing. And there are closed spaces again. Yet, there is something so inherently cool in dual-wielding that I can't help it

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Haha, he is a monster in combat (actual HEMA Instructor) & this isn't even his main profession (he is a blacksmith)!

Now, about that request from Agadris, how fortunate we are that Mick, just made a remake of kukri-master,
right here => kukri-master-fighter-8-weapon-master-22 ... tml#p16534

Just swap the kukris with scimitars, you have super-ab, so you can afford that.
Change exotic weapons with blind-fight.
play the game.

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: Haha, he is a monster in combat (actual HEMA Instructor) & this isn't even his main profession (he is a blacksmith)!

Now, about that request from Agadris, how fortunate we are that Mick, just made a remake of kukri-master,

Just swap the kukris with scimitars, you have super-ab, so you can afford that.
Change exotic weapons with blind-fight.
play the game.
This one is another great build... for purely melee gameplay without stealth. It probably rocks on the open battlefield but lacks this shadow-skulker vibe. I was looking for an assassin who has no problem dealing with everything immune to DA/SA but with higher saves than assassin-builds I've seen here usually have. Add a bit of bard's magic and singing to the mix and you get a sneaky-spellsword of a sort and I personally have a weak spot for those.

Feel free to throw a kukri at me if I'm being too finicky.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I like tough customers, they challenge me so I can become better/explore other areas of the game

Hmm, what about this one then? If you want all saves >20, then simply replace great fortitude/epic fortitude with their "will" counterparts.
You can obviously change the weapon to whatever you want.
the-night-raider-ftr-10-asn-25-rng-5-t2354423.html#p812

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Valerfor, I feel like I'm dancing on the blade here... but as I mentioned above rangers can't be assassins in my opinion because they can't be evil. To become one with the nature, one must take a spiritual journey that changes anyone who walks it completely and irreversibly. I admit that in a particular story you can make your ranger evil by means of a curse or the ranger's getting mad about a devastation of nature or something like that. However, even then that drastic shift of alignment could only be temporary until the curse was lifted or the ranger found their way back to the inner calm they had before this way or another. Btw, in case of a curse scenario the ranger is supposed to loos their connection with nature, the way I see it.

Anyways, I know that this is only applicable from RP point of view but I really can't turn a blind eye to this.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
The problem with the Night Raider, I'm afraid, is the same as with Subtle Death, in that Agadris doesn't want an evil Ranger (bloody principles, eh?).

To get to the bones of the request, though, and taking the feat-starvation in a potential dual-wielding Bard/ BG/ Ass build as a given. Be it human, elf, dwarf, gnome, anything else, you'll need a minimum of 8 levels of Bard before you can take a level in BG (min BAB 6+), or 5 before you can take a level of Assassin (min Hide/ MS 8+) - and if you go for Assassin first that makes it at least 10th level before BG becomes available. And if you want to make best use of BG you'll need reasonable Charisma (which at least has some synergy with Bard). Then you'll need reasonable Dexterity (15+) for Ambidexterity. And then you want a decent Intelligence for both Death Attack DC and available skills. Oh yes, and a bucket-load of Strength. So the build runs the risk of being spread too thin to do anything well, sorry.

Just my very amateur opinion.

Cheers

EDIT: Ninja'd. But I'll let it stand

EDIT 2: Sorry, forgot to mention feats and AB. With this proposed combination there are only the standard 7 available feats pre-epic (8 if going human). Presumably you'll be wanting all 3 dual-wielding ones, Weapon Focus, Power Attack - if you want Divine Might and/or Shield, which would fill all but one spot if human, and all if not. That means flipping a coin between Blind Fight, Knockdown, Imp Crit, and anything else. And if you want the full 4 attacks per round you'll need at least 16 pre-epic BAB, which also puts severe restrictions on which classes you can take, and when.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I see where he comes from, AD&D, where Rangers were only of good-alignment.

That's too bad because I remodeled my original build in order to also have itwf/kukris & faster feat progression & it ticks all the boxes except for the roleplaying one.

It's fine, since I made it, I may as well present it for anyone interested.

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Well, I see your point there, Stag. And I saw that there were the issues you've mentioned as well but there was hope that I simply didn't see a way out. Well, say, we drop the dual-wileding part, could it work? 

I really liked how EasternPromises handled things in his Black Arrow build https://www.tapatalk.com/groups/nwnecbguild/viewtopic.php?p=13825#p13825 and I thought maybe something similar could be done for a melee Bard/BG combo. And the next car of that train of thought was that it could be quite an impressive build if DA with a competitive DC was added.

But if it's something unachievable, then, I guess, I'll have to go with Shadow Avenger or something else. Unless, of course, we drop DW and find some other way to go.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Sorry again, another thing I neglected to mention with the classes involved is that unless you delay Weapon Focus in scimitar, you're stuck with simple weapons until you take a level in Blackguard, or take the Martial Weapons Proficiency feat. Of course, if going elf, you could focus in longsword or rapier.

I do think the single weapon option would work better with the classes you want. And Eastern Promises' build has the mahussive benefit of being an Arcane Archer. It does one thing, and does it very well.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Welcome to the guild Agadris, I hope you enjoy your stay!

If I got you right, you want to build a strength based assassin with a high DC, dual wielding and with 4 + 2 attacks and a bard song to boost it. And magic would be nice to have.
A high and effective Death attack DC needs a lot of assassin levels. That means limited room for everything else. So it has to be narrowed down in one way or the other.
You want no ranger. That one is a pity, because ranger has a lot to offer in assassin builds.
And corrupted rangers can be interesting to roleplay if you give them some depth.
But if it is a no-go, there are other options, not quite so good, but still options.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: TWIN-COBRA STRIKE
This really is a slick build. The way you use - and not use ranger here is sublime.

The best counter attack is probably a well placed bolt.

I know the will save is a little lower than you would like, but there is also this GDL classic to consider

The Assassin King

You could even drop the initiative feats (as far as I know they do bugger all) for save boosters

posts.author: gkorjax
posts.content:
I think you should just consider that Assassins have to be evil as a restriction in the engine. I mean...we've all seen some good arguments that they could easily be considered neutral. Some roleplayers could even have them be good (weeding out bad for the good of all).

The evil label is just something I don't care about when building a character, except I follow the rules of the server I play on .

posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote: Welcome to the guild Agadris, I hope you enjoy your stay!

A high and effective Death attack DC needs a lot of assassin levels. That means limited room for everything else. So it has to be narrowed down in one way or the other.

And corrupted rangers can be interesting to roleplay if you give them some depth.
But if it is a no-go, there are other options, not quite so good, but still options.
Hello Mick and thanks for the warm welcome! 

I know I was trying to cram too much into the build. Even with DW dropped and requirements to the saves lowered, this ship would unlikely sail well. Well, so be it. 

However, what is cycling in my mind now is a Brd/CoT/Rogue combo that could still get me a stealthy strength-based spellcaster (we are talking only about the 'utility' spells and not some real buffs or offense) with more or less efficient Bard Song, high saves and not-the-highest-but-still-nice AB. I'm thinking 8-16 Bard levels, then CoT - enough for the saves to be above 20-23, and Rogue levels for SA and things like Crippling Strike maybe. DW is desirable but optional.

Any ideas?

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
gkorjax wrote: I think you should just consider that Assassins have to be evil as a restriction in the engine. I mean...we've all seen some good arguments that they could easily be considered neutral. Some roleplayers could even have them be good (weeding out bad for the good of all).

The evil label is just something I don't care about when building a character, except I follow the rules of the server I play on .
A good point there gkorjax. However, if you want to progress as an assassin, you cannot allow an alignment shift to happen. I don't know how easy or difficult it is for it to happen on the servers (maybe you don't have to interact with the environment that much so your dialogue choices can't really affect your alignment; I've never played on PWs tbh) but in a singleplayer sometimes you can't avoid going for purely 'evil' choices. 

And this leads to that you can't really roleplay an evil character who seeks redemption in their sometimes very biased ways or who fights 'greater' evil in a Machiavellian style because of the options are 'I want to rob this guy', 'I want to murder this guy for no obvious reason simply because I'm evil', 'I won't help this guy because he is weak' and so on. 

Writers rarely allow you not to rob the guy because money is something you don't really care about since you are sure that you'll get plenty of it after killing some local province-grade villains. They rarely allow you to just pass by the guy without killing him or to just scare the hell out of him so that he never-ever tries to cross you again. And you can never justify that you agreed to help a weak one because your hatred towards his offenders was greater than your contempt towards the guy.

Probably one of the best examples of a pragmatic evil behavior is Shepard murdering that batarian engineer in cold blood on the mission to get the old Vakarian out of trouble and off the Omega.

No need to give up on assassin yet.
Here is a dual-wielding strength based assassin, using bard as stepping stone.
It has some low level magic and can also use UMD for spellcasting. AB +41. You play him in medium armor. You may start out with chain mail, but move to chain shirt for better AC and less armor penalty once you find a way to buff dex to 18.

I like this one more Mick. Despite it having just 3 APR without DW and only 2 levels in spellcasting. Do you think it would be okay to drop the Spot and add some thievery skills (setting/disabling traps and lockipicking) to make the build a bit more versatile? 

I also would like to grab this opportunity to ask if a stealth-based character needs concentration? I guess it's okay if you go without it having HiPS or Darkness in your toolkit to avoid taunts in open combat but what if you can only strike from the shadows once and then have to deal with the rest in a toe-to-toe fighting?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Mick to the rescue!
Well, he was our last weapon.
If anybody here could satisfy a (tough-as-nails) request for an assassin build & he did.

Just so that you'll know though, I didn't abandon you either Agadris & I did make a whole new build, Bard 16/ Blackguard 4/ Assassin 20, with all your requirements & then I threw it to the recycle bin.
It took me all the feats up to level 36, just to nail the feats requirements (BG's also need cleave) & it's final ab while dual-wielding scimy's was 33.
It wasn't pretty.

And as Mick said, don't give-up on the assassin yet.

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: Mick to the rescue!
Well, he was our last weapon.

Just so that you'll know though, I didn't abandon you either Agadris & I did make a whole new build, Bard 16/ Blackguard 4/ Assassin 20, with all your requirements & then I threw it to the recycle bin.
It took me all the feats up to level 36, just to nail the feats requirements (BG's also need cleave) & it's final ab while dual-wielding scimy's was 33.
It wasn't pretty.

And as Mick said, don't give-up on the assassin yet.
Thank you Valerfor! 

I also tried to build something around Brd 12/16, BG 4, Asn 20/24 in-game (CBC just frustrates me every time I try to use it; perhaps, I'm too dumb for it or too lazy... or maybe a bit of both)... And I confirmed  the impossibility of the task to myself as well. 

That's when I remembered this Shadow Knight build available here https://steamcommunity.com/groups/NWN-P ... 428424206/ and thought that maybe it wasn't an absolutely bad idea to add spellcasting to that STR-based sneaky-type by throwing some Bard mojo into the mix. Maybe 8-16 Bard levels for the song and some magic? 

Then again, giving up on Asn could be a good thing because I too sometimes find it difficult to play an evil character. Lawful Stupid is still less annoying to me than Illogical Evil.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Agadris wrote: Do you think it would be okay to drop the Spot and add some thievery skills (setting/disabling traps and lockipicking) to make the build a bit more versatile? 

I also would like to grab this opportunity to ask if a stealth-based character needs concentration? I guess it's okay if you go without it having HiPS or Darkness in your toolkit to avoid taunts in open combat but what if you can only strike from the shadows once and then have to deal with the rest in a toe-to-toe fighting? 
I am glad you like the build Agadris 

As for skills: This build has two detection skills, both Spot and Listen, but can work with only one of them. The build also has 10 spare skill points. 
If you have access to true seeing, Listen is best. If not, I prefer Spot in an assassin build. Spot makes you see hiding creatures within line of sight. Listen reveals creatures behind walls and moving creatures trying to stalk you, but hiding, static creatures tend to disappear once they enter your line of sight.
You want to take your main detection skill early so you have it available throughout your game. Your excess skill points will come in epic levels. That is why I take Listen so late. This build has a low dex bonus and will need many ranks in trap setting and lock opening. Dex builds are better at that. You can always allocate a couple of skill points early on to unlock the skills if you want to dabble in the arts, but you will not be good at it before late in epic levels.
If I should play this build, I would resort to casting Knock and Detect traps instead of using thievery skills, either from a wand or from scrolls.
You are right about Concentration and Taunt. The reason why I don't take it here, is because it is only a class skill up to level 24 and excess skillpoints only become available later. And I don't want to give it priority over Discipline, Hide, Move silently, Spot, Tumble and UMD. That is also why there is no Spellcraft in the build.
